messageBody:
RE: Method Chains, was Re: Testing private methodsAlternatively,
change from:

public class A {
public void f() {
b = new B();
b.doSomething();
}
}

to:

public class A {
public void f(B b) {
b.doSomething(aValue());
}
}

The test then becomes:

public class TestA {
public void testF() {
A anA = new A(aValue);
MockB mockB = new MockB();
mockB.setExpectedSomething(aValue);

a.f(mockB);

mockB.verify();
}
}

We have found that changing to a style where you pass behaviours around, rather than data, avoids things like subclassing production code in a test and pushes the code to flexing in the 'right' kinda ways. If you can figure out what to pass in and what to verify, then the rest of the test usually falls out.

Steve
